questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the physician because of weakness in his right hand for the past 3 months. He works as a violinist in a professional orchestra. Physical examination shows atrophy of the thenar and dorsal interosseus muscles of the right hand. Sensation to pinprick and vibration is normal. A cross-section of the spinal cord at the level of C6 is shown. The most likely cause of this patient's symptoms is damage to which of the following labeled structures?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Structure A is the left fasciculus gracilis. Damage to this structure leads to a loss of sensory functions (pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception) of the left lower body and legs. This loss of function is seen in conditions such as tabes dorsalis and subacute combined degeneration. Muscle atrophy and weakness would not be expected. Moreover, the patient's preserved sensation to pinprick and vibration rules out this possibility.

B) INCORRECT:

Structure B is the left fasciculus cuneatus. Damage to this structure leads to a loss of sensory functions (pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception) in the left upper body and arm, which is seen in conditions such as tabes dorsalis and subacute combined degeneration. Muscle atrophy and weakness would not be expected. Moreover, the patient's preserved sensation to pinprick and vibration rules out this possibility.

C) INCORRECT:

Structure C is the left lateral corticospinal tract. Damage to this structure would lead to signs of upper motor neuron damage on the left side of the body (e.g., increased muscle tone and reflexes). This patient presents with lower motor neuron symptoms of the right side of the body, ruling out this possibility.

D) INCORRECT:

Structure D is the left dorsolateral column in the anterior horn. Damage to this structure would lead to signs of lower motor neuron damage (e.g., muscle weakness, reduced muscle tone, loss of reflexes) of the distal portion of the left limbs. This patient's lower motor neuron signs are on the right side of his body, not the left.

E) INCORRECT:

Structure E is the left dorsomedial column in the anterior horn. Damage to this structure would lead to signs of lower motor neuron damage (e.g., muscle weakness, reduced muscle tone, loss of reflexes) on the left side of the body in the region of the shoulder and the proximal extensor muscles. This patient presents with signs of lower motor neuron damage in the right hand, not in the left proximal arm or shoulders.

F) INCORRECT:

Structure F is the right dorsomedial column in the anterior horn. Damage to the right medial group of the anterior horn would lead to signs of lower motor neuron damage (e.g., muscle weakness, reduced muscle tone, loss of reflexes) on the right side of the body in the region of the shoulder and the proximal extensor muscles. This patient presents with signs of lower motor neuron damage in the hand, not in the proximal arm or shoulders.

G) CORRECT:

Structure G, the right dorsolateral column in the anterior horn, is responsible for this patient's symptoms. This patient's presentation of atrophy restricted to the thenar eminence is a common early sign of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), known as split-hand syndrome. While the corticospinal tracts (structures C and H) are also often damaged in ALS, this patient has no signs of upper motor neuron damage (e.g., increased muscle tone and reflexes).

H) INCORRECT:

Structure H is the right lateral corticospinal tract. Damage to this structure would lead to signs of upper motor neuron damage (e.g., increased muscle tone and reflexes) on the right side of the body. The patient's presentation with lower motor neuron symptoms rules out this possibility.

I) INCORRECT:

Structure I is the right fasciculus cuneatus. Damage to this structure leads to a loss of the sensory functions (pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception) of the right upper body and arm, which is seen in conditions such as tabes dorsalis and subacute combined degeneration. Muscle atrophy and weakness would not be expected. Moreover, the patient's preserved sensation to pinprick and vibration rules out this possibility.

J) INCORRECT:

Structure J is the right fasciculus gracilis. Damage to this structure leads to a loss of sensory functions (pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception) of the right lower body and leg, which is seen in conditions such as tabes dorsalis and subacute combined degeneration. Muscle atrophy and weakness would not be expected. Moreover, the patient's preserved sensation to pinprick and vibration rules out this possibility.
questions.hint: Muscle atrophy and weakness are signs of lower motor neuron damage.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. Three weeks ago, she was diagnosed with herpes zoster in the right T10 dermatome. The rash has since resolved, but she now reports continuous burning and stabbing pain in the affected area. During the neurologic examination, the physician tests the patient's pain and temperature sensation on the right lower abdomen. Which of the following labeled parts of the upper thoracic spinal cord is responsible for transmitting this sensory information?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A is the left gracile fasciculus, which carries impulses from the lower body. Together with the cuneate fasciculus, it ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal column, conveying proprioception, vibration, and fine touch.

B) INCORRECT:

B is the left cuneate fasciculus, which carries impulses from the upper body (excluding the face and ear). Together with the gracile fasciculus, it ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal column, conveying proprioception, vibration, and fine touch.

C) CORRECT:

C is the left lateral spinothalamic tract. The spinothalamic tract consists of ascending sensory nerve fibers, which transmit the sensations of pain and temperature (lateral tract) as well as the sensations of pressure and crude touch (anterior tract). First-order neurons are located within the dorsal root ganglia, where their axons enter the spinal cord and ascend or descend 1–2 segments to form synapses with the second-order neurons, which are located in the posterior horn of the gray matter. Axons of the second-order neurons cross to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure to ascend contralaterally in the spinothalamic tract to the thalamus. Accordingly, the left spinothalamic tract in an upper thoracic segment transmits the sensations of pain and temperature from the right T10 dermatome.
Image Description:

Left image: the dorsal column (gracile fasciculus and cuneate fasciculus) carries information of fine touch, vibration, pressure, and proprioception (gracile fasciculus: primarily from the lower half of the body; cuneate fasciculus: primarily from the upper half of the body).

Right side: the anterolateral column (anterior spinothalamic tract and lateral spinothalamic tract) carries information of crude touch, pressure, pain, and temperature.
1) Anterior spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Axons from the first neuron split and ascend or descend several segments (a). Having reached another segment, they synapse to the second neuron in the posterior horn of the spinal cord, and the axons decussate to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (b). Further ascend in the anterior spinothalamic tract (c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).
2) Lateral spinothalamic tract: The first neuron is located within the spinal ganglia. Synapse to the 2nd neuron in the gray matter on the same segment. The axon of the 2nd neuron decussates to the contralateral side of the spinal cord within the anterior white commissure (a). Ascend in the lateral spinothalamic tract (b, c, d). Synapse to the 3rd neuron in the thalamus (e).

Both pathways end in the somatosensory cortex and transmit sensory information.

D) INCORRECT:

D is the left anterior spinothalamic tract, which contains ascending sensory nerves that transmit the sensations of crude touch and pressure.

E) INCORRECT:

E is the right anterior spinothalamic tract, which contains ascending sensory nerves that transmit the sensations of crude touch and pressure.

F) INCORRECT:

F is the right lateral spinothalamic tract, which contains sensory nerves that transmit pain and temperature. The axons of the first-order neurons of the lateral spinothalamic tract enter the ipsilateral spinal cord and ascend or descend several segments before they form synapses with second-order neurons. Then axons of the second-order neurons cross to the contralateral side of the spinal cord to ascend contralaterally in the spinothalamic tract. This patient's pain and temperature sensation in the right T10 dermatome is tested. The ipsilateral lateral spinothalamic tract would not be affected in this patient because the cross-section of the spinal cord shown is at the upper thoracic level. Therefore, the second-order neuron rather than the first-order neuron would be affected.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the arrangement of the spinal cord pathways within the white matter of the spinal cord

Ascending sensory tracts (blue)
1) Dorsal columns: relay conscious proprioception, pressure, vibration, and fine touch to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
2) Spinocerebellar tract: relays unconscious proprioception to the ipsilateral cerebellum
3) Anterolateral spinothalamic tract: relays pressure, crude touch, pain, and temperature to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
4) Spino-olivary tract: responsible for relaying unconscious proprioception (mainly for balance) to the olivary nucleus in the ipsilateral medulla and, from there, to the ipsilateral cerebellum

Descending tracts (red)
5) Pyramidal tract: controls voluntary movement by transmitting impulses from the precentral gyrus of the brain to the contralateral side of the body
6) Extrapyramidal tract: regulates involuntary movements and reflexes by transmitting impulses from the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum to the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
Somatotopic organization: C = cervical, T = thoracic, L = lumbar, S = sacral

G) INCORRECT:

G is the right cuneate fasciculus, which carries impulses from the upper body (excluding the face and ear). Together with the gracile fasciculus, it ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal column, conveying proprioception, vibration, and fine touch.

H) INCORRECT:

H is the right gracile fasciculus, which carries impulses from the lower body. Together with the cuneate fasciculus, it ascends ipsilaterally in the dorsal column, conveying proprioception, vibration, and fine touch.
questions.hint: Sensation to pain and temperature is transmitted to the thalamus by the lateral spinothalamic tract.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after a motor vehicle collision. He is not responsive to verbal commands and is unable to provide any history. His pulse is 108/min and regular. Physical examination shows ecchymoses over the neck and back. Neurological examination indicates damage to the spinal cord at the level shown in the illustration. This patient's injury is most likely located at which of the following levels of the spinal cord?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The spinal cord level of L4 generally has more gray matter, less white matter, and larger ventral horns compared to the cervical and thoracic segments and does not contain lateral horns as seen in the illustration.

B) INCORRECT:

The spinal cord level of C2 generally has less gray matter and more white matter compared to the other spinal segments and does not contain lateral horns as seen in the illustration.

C) INCORRECT:

Though the spinal cord levels S2–S4 contain lateral horns, they do not form prominent lateral projections between the dorsal and ventral horns as seen in the illustration. In addition, the sacral portions of the spinal cord contain much less white matter than the spinal segment in the illustration. White matter contains the axons of neurons as they travel between the brain and the rest of the body; at the sacral level, there are fewer axons traveling up to the brain compared to more superior levels of the spinal cord. Thus, gray matter forms a greater proportion of the sacral spinal cord.

D) INCORRECT:

Though the spinal cord levels S2–S4 contain lateral horns, they do not form prominent lateral projections between the dorsal and ventral horns as seen in the illustration. In addition, the sacral portions of the spinal cord contain much less white matter than the spinal segment in the illustration. White matter contains the axons of neurons as they travel between the brain and the rest of the body; at the sacral level, there are fewer axons traveling up to the brain compared to more superior levels of the spinal cord. Thus, gray matter forms a greater proportion of the sacral spinal cord.

E) CORRECT:

Cross-sections of the spinal cord show butterfly-shaped gray matter with surrounding white matter. Gray matter contains the cell bodies of neurons; white matter contains the axons of neurons as they travel between the brain and the rest of the body. In general, gray matter is divided into three regions: dorsal horns, ventral horns, and lateral horns. Dorsal and ventral horns are found throughout the spinal cord. Though lateral horns are present between segments T1–L3 and segments S2–S4, only segments T1–L3 have the prominent lateral projections between the dorsal and ventral horns as seen in the illustration. Thus, this patient's injury must be located within these segments.
Image Description:

The transverse width of the spinal cord varies significantly depending on the level. It is largest at the cervical (C4/5) and lumbar (L4/5) enlargements, where neurons of the brachial and lumbosacral plexus are located. The white matter is a collection of nerve fibers and decreases in size as it descends, as descending fibers decrease from cranial to caudal, and ascending fibers increase from caudal to cranial.

Important structures of the gray and white matter are marked in the image.
questions.hint: The illustration shows a segment of the spinal cord that contains prominent lateral projections between the dorsal and ventral horns. These projections are lateral horns, which contain neuronal cell bodies of the sympathetic nervous system.

questions.text: A 69-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of right-sided body weakness for 1 hour. Neurologic examination shows deviation of the tongue to the left when protruded and decreased sensation to vibration and position in the right extremities. Muscle strength is 2/5 in the right lower extremity and 1/5 in the right upper extremity. Plantar reflex shows an extensor response on the right side. A CT scan of the head and neck shows a brainstem lesion. A schematic section of the brainstem at the level of the medulla oblongata is shown. The patient's symptoms are most likely to be caused by a lesion in which of the following labeled areas?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This area contains the right pyramidal tract, right medial lemniscus, and axons of the right hypoglossal nucleus. Opposite to the presentation seen in this patient, a lesion in this region would cause hemiparesis and hemisensory loss on the left (rather than the right) side of the body, and the tongue would deviate to the right (rather than left) upon protrusion.

B) INCORRECT:

This area identifies the right inferior olivary nucleus (ION), which provides innervation to the contralateral (i.e., left) cerebellar nuclei. The cerebellar nuclei control motor coordination in the ipsilateral half of the body. Damage to the right ION would cause anterograde transneuronal degeneration of the left cerebellar nuclei and therefore present with left-sided hemiataxia rather than the right-sided hemiparesis and hypoglossal nerve palsy seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

This area contains the right lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, and sympathetic fibers. Damage to the right lateral spinothalamic tract and the right spinal trigeminal nucleus causes left-sided loss of pain and temperature sensations, unlike the right-sided loss of proprioception and vibration sensation that are seen here. In addition, hemiparesis or deviation of the tongue are inconsistent with a lesion in this region. Instead, other features of an ipsilateral lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) such as right-sided palate weakness (deviation of the uvula to the left), nystagmus, vertigo, and right-sided Horner syndrome would be expected.

D) INCORRECT:

This area contains the left lateral spinothalamic tract, spinal trigeminal nucleus, nucleus ambiguus, vestibular nuclei, and sympathetic fibers. Damage to the left lateral spinothalamic tract and the left spinal trigeminal nucleus causes contralateral (i.e., right-sided) hemisensory loss, which is seen here, but pain and temperature sensations rather than proprioception and vibration would also be affected. In addition, hemiparesis or deviation of the tongue is not consistent with a lesion in this region. Instead, other features of an ipsilateral lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) such as left-sided palate weakness (deviation of the uvula to the right), nystagmus, vertigo, and left-sided Horner syndrome would be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

This area corresponds to the left inferior olivary nucleus (ION), which provides innervation to the contralateral (i.e., right) cerebellar nuclei. The cerebellar nuclei control motor coordination in the ipsilateral half of the body. Damage to the left ION causes anterograde transneuronal degeneration of the right cerebellar nuclei and therefore presents with right-sided hemiataxia. Hemiparesis and hypoglossal nerve palsy, as seen in this patient, are inconsistent with a lesion in this area.

F) CORRECT:

This area contains the left pyramidal tract (descending motor tract) and left medial lemniscus (an ascending sensory tract) at the level of the cranial medulla (i.e., level of the inferior olivary nuclei). At this level, the pyramidal tract and medial lemniscus have not yet decussated to the contralateral side. A lesion in this area causes medial medullary syndrome with features of upper motor neuron hemiparesis as well as a loss of proprioception, vibration, and fine touch in the contralateral (i.e., right) side of the body, as seen here. In addition, the axons of the ipsilateral (i.e., left) hypoglossal nerve (CN XII) pass through this area; damage to these fibers causes ipsilateral intrinsic tongue muscle weakness, which manifests as a deviation of the tongue to the side of weakness.
Image Description:

Transverse section

Typically, the efferent cranial nuclei are located medially while the afferent nuclei are located more laterally.
questions.hint: This transverse section is taken from the cranial portion of the medulla oblongata, as evidenced by the visibility of the fourth ventricle in the posterior aspect and the emergence of hypoglossal nerves and vagus nerves (from the preolivary sulci and postolivary sulci respectively) in the anterior aspect. Occlusion of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery can cause infarction of the area affected in this patient.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man with a history of gastric cancer that was treated with subtotal gastrectomy dies in a motor vehicle collision. At autopsy, examination of the spinal cord shows unilateral atrophy of the neurons in the area indicated by the arrow. Neurological examination of the patient when he was still alive would most likely have shown which of the following findings?

choices.text: Decreased sense of pain in the contralateral leg
Decreased sense of temperature in the ipsilateral arm
Decreased strength of the contralateral leg
Decreased vibratory sense in the ipsilateral arm
Decreased positional sense in the ipsilateral leg
Decreased sense of crude touch in the contralateral arm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The sensations of pain and temperature are carried by the afferent neurons that run in the lateral spinothalamic tract of the spinal cord. These neurons decussate 1–2 spinal nerve segments above the point of entry. Therefore, atrophy of these neurons can result in decreased sensitivity to pain and temperature on the ipsilateral side of the body at the level of the lesion and on the contralateral side two segments below the lesion. However, the atrophic area in this patient does not correspond to the lateral spinothalamic tract.

B) INCORRECT:

The sensations of pain and temperature are carried by the afferent neurons that run in the lateral spinothalamic tract of the spinal cord. These neurons decussate 1–2 spinal nerve segments above the point of entry. Therefore, atrophy of these neurons can result in decreased sensitivity to pain and temperature on the ipsilateral side of the body at the level of the lesion and on the contralateral side two segments below the lesion. However, the atrophic area in this patient does not correspond to the lateral spinothalamic tract.

C) INCORRECT:

Voluntary limb movement is controlled by the lateral corticospinal tract, which is formed by the axons of pyramidal neurons located in the primary motor cortex. The axons decussate at the caudal medulla. Lesions above the caudal medulla result in contralateral limb weakness, while lesions in the spinal cord result in ipsilateral weakness. However, the atrophic area in this patient does not correspond to the lateral corticospinal tract.

D) INCORRECT:

Atrophy of the fasciculus cuneatus can result in decreased proprioception, vibration, pressure, and fine touch sensation in the ipsilateral arm and upper trunk. However, the atrophic area in this patient does not correspond to the fasciculus cuneatus.

E) CORRECT:

The area indicated by the arrow corresponds to the fasciculus gracilis of the dorsal column. This part of the spinal cord consists of afferent neurons, which transmit the sensations of proprioception, vibration, pressure, and fine touch from the ipsilateral lower trunk and extremities. Atrophy of this area due to neuronal demyelination can be caused by vitamin B12 deficiency and results in decreased function of these neurons, leading to decreased positional sense (i.e., proprioception) and vibratory sensation in the ipsilateral leg.

Vitamin B12 deficiency can also lead to combined degeneration of the dorsal and lateral columns of the spinal cord (i.e., subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord), which classically manifests with decreased proprioception and vibratory sensation, spasticity, and ataxia.
Image Description:

Illustration depicting the arrangement of the spinal cord pathways within the white matter of the spinal cord

Ascending sensory tracts (blue)
1) Dorsal columns: relay conscious proprioception, pressure, vibration, and fine touch to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
2) Spinocerebellar tract: relays unconscious proprioception to the ipsilateral cerebellum
3) Anterolateral spinothalamic tract: relays pressure, crude touch, pain, and temperature to the contralateral somatosensory cortex of the brain
4) Spino-olivary tract: responsible for relaying unconscious proprioception (mainly for balance) to the olivary nucleus in the ipsilateral medulla and, from there, to the ipsilateral cerebellum

Descending tracts (red)
5) Pyramidal tract: controls voluntary movement by transmitting impulses from the precentral gyrus of the brain to the contralateral side of the body
6) Extrapyramidal tract: regulates involuntary movements and reflexes by transmitting impulses from the basal ganglia, brain stem, and cerebellum to the anterior horn cells of the spinal cord
Somatotopic organization: C = cervical, T = thoracic, L = lumbar, S = sacral

F) INCORRECT:

The sensations of crude touch and pressure are transmitted through afferent neurons that run in the anterior spinothalamic tract. These neurons decussate 1–2 spinal nerve segments above the point of entry. Therefore, atrophy of these neurons can result in decreased sensitivity to pain and temperature on the contralateral side of the body. However, the atrophic area in this patient does not correspond to the anterior spinothalamic tract.
questions.hint: The region of the spinal cord indicated in the image is affected by vitamin B12 deficiency, which occurs in about 15% of patients with prior subtotal gastrectomy (due to insufficient intrinsic factor synthesis).
